I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the country programming mission in December 2010, the Government of the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide 
technical  assistance  (TA)  for  improving  energy  efficiency  and  reducing  emissions  through 
intelligent railway station buildings (IRSBs). A fact-finding mission visited the PRC in August 
2011 and reached agreement with the government on the TA’s impact, outcome, outputs, 
implementation  arrangements,  cost,  financing  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference  for 
consultants. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The PRC has sustained high levels of economic growth since the open door policy and 
economic reforms were initiated. Gross domestic product increased from $268.3 billion in 1978 
to $5,878.6 billion in 2010, with an annual growth rate of 10.1%. With rapid industrialization and 
urbanization, however, energy consumption and carbon emissions have increased at a great 
pace. The PRC has replaced the United States as the largest carbon emitter since 2007 and 
become the world’s largest energy consumer since 2010. Growing energy consumption and 
emissions raise serious concerns. The International Energy Agency predicts that world primary 
energy demand will increase by 36% between 2008 and 2035. The PRC’s demand will rise by 
75%, accounting for 36% of the projected growth in global energy use.2 In order to manage the 
growth in energy demand, the government has planned to reduce energy consumption and 
carbon dioxide emissions by 16% and 17% respectively for each unit of gross domestic product 
during the 12th Five-Year Plan period (2011–2015). 
 
3.  Railways play an important role in transportation in the PRC due to the country’s large 
land area and population. The government has been increasing the railway transport capacity to 
meet the needs of economic and social development. During 1980–2010, the railway network 
increased from 53,321 kilometers (km) to 91,000 km, an average annual increase of 1.8%. Over 
the same period, however, railway passenger traffic increased from 138.3 billion passenger-km 
to 876.2 billion passenger-km, an annual growth rate of 6.35%. Meanwhile, railway freight traffic 
grew  from  571.8 billion  ton-km  to  2,764.4  billion  ton-km,  an  annual  rate  of  5.39%.  The 
government recognizes that railways offer an environmentally friendly mode of transport while 
providing an important way to spur economic growth, generate employment opportunities, and 
reduce  poverty.  It  plans  to  sustain  railway  development  through  the  12th  Five-Year  Plan, 
particularly by developing railways in poorer and undeveloped provinces that will contribute to 
economic growth and reduce poverty and improve livelihoods for people served by new railways 
by  ensuring  cost-effective  and  fast  access  to  markets,  educational,  and  health  facilities; 
generating employment opportunities during construction and operation; and improving social 
services. The plan envisages (i) removing transport bottlenecks and enhancing railway transport 
capacity; (ii) increasing railway operating mileage to 120,000 km, including 50,000 km in the 
less-developed western region; (iii) optimizing the structure of the railway network while making 
50% of the network’s length double-track and 60% of it electrified; (iv) increasing passenger and 
freight volumes to 3 billion persons and 4.8 billion tons, which will be 78.6% and 32.2% greater 
than  in  2010,  respectively;  and  (v)  constructing  and  reconstructing  about  1,000  railway 
passenger stations. 
 
4.  The PRC’s railway is a growing energy end-user. Between 2000 and 2010, its electricity 
consumption grew by 181.4% from 12.64 billion to 35.57 billion kilowatt-hours (annual growth of

10.9%).3 With rapid increases in traffic volume and a rising share of electrified railways, railway 
electricity  consumption  will  continue  to  grow  in  future.  PRC  railways  will  consume  around 
59.7 billion  kilowatt-hours  in  2015,  an  increase  of  68%  compared  with  2010.  In  order  to 
moderate the increasing energy use, the Ministry of Railways (MOR) has committed to improve 
energy efficiency. It achieved its mandatory target to reduce the average energy use per unit of 
traffic volume (railway energy intensity) by 20% during the 11th Five-Year Plan period and has 
set a new target to further reduce it by 10% during the 12th Five-Year Plan. 
 
5.  Railway stations are a core component of the railway network and critical to its effective 
operation. MOR has around 5,300 railway stations, including 1,624 railway passenger stations. 
They are often busy and crowded, with billions of passengers gathering and dispatching on 
trains annually. Most stations were designed and constructed long ago following conventional 
technical  standards  and  methods  without  much  consideration  for  energy  efficiency  and 
environmental protection. Even newly built railway stations that generally were designed for 
improved aesthetics, functionality, and connection with other transport modes were designed 
without  adequate  attention  to  energy  efficiency  and  integration  of  both  railway  operating 
subsystems and station building subsystems. 
 
6.  Around 40% of the world’s energy is consumed by buildings. Since the 1980s, intelligent 
buildings technology has been developed to integrate energy efficiency and environmental 
friendliness into building design. Without sacrificing comfort, such technology can result in 
energy savings of 25%−30% and corresponding carbon emission reductions.4 It has made 
significant  inroads  into  improving  energy  consumption  in  public  and  residential  buildings, 
particularly in developed countries. IRSBs using intelligent building technology can therefore 
contribute to MOR meeting its energy intensity reduction target. 
 
7.  MOR has made efforts to improve energy efficiency in railway stations by updating 
electrical equipment and lighting and air-conditioning systems. However, these improvements 
would be insufficient to achieve the plan’s targets. MOR believes it is necessary to introduce an 
IRSB  concept  that  integrates  the  latest  thinking  and  technologies  in  building  design, 
environmental preservation, energy savings, and operating efficiency. This concept would lead 
to a new technical design standard for railway station construction and operations. By adopting 
IRSBs, MOR wishes to (i) reduce energy use without compromising traffic growth and comfort, 
(ii) reduce greenhouse gas emissions, (iii) improve service quality and safety, and (iv) decrease 
operating costs. 
 
8.  Through policy dialogue, ADB has been supporting the PRC’s efforts to develop a 
sustainable, intelligent, and environment-friendly railway system with high quality services and 
efficiency. In Strategy 20205 and the Sustainable Transport Initiative Operational Plan,6 ADB 
has identified railways as a core operational subsector and achieving sustainability, energy 
efficiency, and emissions reduction as a strategic priority. In its support for PRC railways, ADB

has focused increasingly on making railways more sustainable.7 The present TA will focus on 
energy efficiency and greenhouse gas emissions reduction in railway stations while providing 
policy recommendations and preparing an action plan to develop IRSBs. It will help MOR 
achieve its new targets of energy efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas emissions under the 
12th Five-Year Plan through using IRSBs.8 The TA will also contribute to developing sustainable, 
intelligent, and environment-friendly railways in the PRC. Additionally, it will explore the potential 
for developing an IRSB demonstration project that could be suitable for ADB financing in the 
PRC, with scope for replication within the PRC and in other developing member countries. 
 
9.  IRSB is a new concept for MOR, and developing IRSBs will be a challenge as MOR has 
little experience and relevant knowledge. Energy efficiency and emissions reduction are urgent 
requirements for inclusive growth and sustainable railway development, and these have been 
included in the government’s 12th Five-Year Plan as mandated targets. Hence, through the TA, 
the government seeks ADB’s assistance to research and learn from international best practices 
on IRSB and adapt them for use in PRC railways. The TA will complement ADB’s ongoing 
efforts to assist the PRC in developing a sustainable, intelligent, and environmentally friendly 
railway system with high quality services and efficiency. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA will be a more energy-efficient, environment-friendly, and intelligent 
railway system developed in the PRC. The achievement of this impact will be demonstrated by 
improved energy efficiency and reduced emissions through IRSBs. The outcome of the TA will 
be that recommendations for IRSB development, railway station energy efficiency assessment 
methodologies, and action plans for applying IRSBs are endorsed by MOR to enhance energy 
efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the railway sector. As a result of the TA, it is 
expected that MOR will adopt relevant policy recommendations on IRSBs and take actions to 
develop IRSBs in the PRC by applying intelligent building technologies. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  To  achieve  these  objectives,  the  TA  will  (i)  provide  recommendations  for  IRSB 
development in the PRC, (ii) develop an energy efficiency and emissions assessment method 
for railway stations, and (iii) prepare an action plan and a policy brief. 
 
12.  The main activities of the TA will be to (i) review the current national building standards 
for energy conservation and the current practices for energy efficiency and emissions in the 
PRC railway stations; (ii) build a database of best international practices applicable for IRSBs, 
covering  (a)  technologies  and  systems,  (b)  design  concepts  and  criteria,  (c) operational 
management methods, (d) strategic management, and (e) ranking practices including according 
to  efficiency,  cost,  and  difficulty  of  implementation;  (iii)  recommend  IRSB  technologies, 
management,  and  practices  to  MOR  with  a  view  to  having  these  approved,  piloted,  and

mainstreamed; (iv) establish detailed energy efficiency and emissions indicators to monitor and 
assess  the  energy  efficiency  and  emissions  reduction  of  MOR’s  railways;  (v)  propose  an 
assessment  method  leading  to  recommendations  for  applications  of  the  aforesaid 
recommended issues through adopting best practices that can be used in the PRC; (vi) prepare 
an action plan with a brief strategy note for applying IRSBs in MOR covering technology, policy, 
management, staff training needs, and recommendation of an IRSB demonstration project that 
can be supported by ADB and potentially be replicated in the PRC and other developing 
member countries; and (vii) prepare a policy brief highlighting the main findings of the TA and 
making the case for the recommended changes. The TA will also provide capacity building 
support through an international study tour for MOR officials to visit best practices of IRSBs and 
other intelligent buildings and through domestic training and knowledge sharing. 
 
13.  The  TA  will  involve  research,  fieldwork,  training,  stakeholder  consultations,  and 
knowledge transfer. The TA will include two workshops, at inception and interim report stages, 
to discuss and review the TA findings. A seminar will be arranged at the final report stage to 
disseminate the international best practices and TA findings. The TA will be undertaken in close 
consultation  with  relevant  departments  in  MOR,  the  government,  user  groups,  the  private 
sector,  international  development  partners,  and  other  relevant  agencies.  It  will  take  into 
consideration  previous  studies  carried  out  by  the  government,  ADB,  the  World  Bank,  the 
Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development, other multilateral agencies, and 
bilateral agencies. MOR will provide the consultants with all relevant materials, recent studies, 
and reports required for the TA, and will also assist in arranging the workshops and seminar and 
liaising with government agencies concerned and with other stakeholders. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The government has requested ADB to finance $400,000 equivalent. The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) to 
cover the entire foreign exchange cost and a portion of the local currency cost. The government 
will provide counterpart staff, office space with furniture, utilities and telecommunication access, 
local transport, and other services to finance the total costs such as remuneration of counterpart 
staff and services. (See Appendix 2 for details of the cost estimates and financing plan.) 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  MOR will be the executing agency for the TA and be responsible for supervising and 
monitoring TA activities. A leading group comprising representatives of relevant departments of 
MOR will be established to oversee implementation and provide guidance to the consultants. A 
project  coordinator  will  be  assigned  to  supervise  and  coordinate  day-to-day  TA  activities, 
including to monitor progress, resolve problems, arrange meetings, and liaise with the relevant 
departments  in  MOR  and  other  agencies  concerned.  MOR  will  also  provide  sufficient 
counterpart staff with relevant work experience during TA implementation. 
 
16.  A team of international and national consultants will be engaged by ADB through a 
consulting firm using the quality- and cost-based selection method with 90% weight given to 
quality and 10% to cost of services, and using simplified technical proposal procedures in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The international and national consultants will have expertise and experience in intelligent 
buildings,  railway  buildings,  railway  electrical  systems,  railway  operation,  railway  energy 
efficiency, and IRSB development. The 90:10 weighting is appropriate because (i) the TA 
comprises an advanced assignment requiring a high degree of expertise in using intelligent 
building technology to reduce energy use, and (ii) the TA is likely to have a significant impact on

5
future development of energy efficient and environment-friendly railway systems in the PRC. 
Two international consultants will provide a total of 8 person-months of services, and up to 5 
national consultants will render a total of 16 person-months of services. The outline terms of 
reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
17.  The  TA  funds  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). An advance payment facility 
can be used to conduct training seminars and conferences. Any procurement under this TA will 
be conducted in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time 
to time). 
 
18.  TA implementation is expected to begin in April 2012 and be completed by September 
2012. The consultants will submit the following reports to MOR and ADB: (i) an inception report 
3 weeks after commencement of services, (ii) an interim report 12 weeks after commencement 
of services, (iii) a draft final report after 18 weeks, and (iv) a final report 2 weeks after receipt of 
review comments from the executing agency and ADB. The final report will include but not be 
limited to (i) a study report and recommendations for IRSB development in the PRC; (ii) the 
action plans for IRSB development in the PRC; (iii) an IRSB demonstration project that can be 
supported by ADB; (iv) a policy note summarizing the best practices, findings, and outcome of 
the TA; and (v) an executive summary of key activities, findings, and recommendations not 
exceeding five pages. All reports shall be submitted in English. 
 
19.  Major project activities will be regularly monitored by and reported to ADB administration 
missions  and  MOR.  Consultants  will  present  their  findings  at  workshops  and  seminars 
organized to validate and disseminate their findings, and reports will be made available on 
ADB’s website in English and Chinese. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Improving  Energy  Efficiency  and 
Reducing Emissions through Intelligent Railway Station Buildings, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) 
for a study on improving energy efficiency and reducing emissions through intelligent railway 
station buildings (IRSBs) will help the government and Ministry of Railways (MOR) by preparing 
policy recommendations on developing IRSBs. The TA will 
(i)  assess  the  current  design  of  railway  station  buildings and  associated  systems, 
including  building  automation  systems;  information  and  communication  network 
systems;  safety,  fire  protection,  and  exit  systems;  heating,  ventilating,  and  air-
conditioning systems; electrical installation systems; lighting systems; hydraulic and 
drainage systems; in-building transportation systems; building façade systems; and 
in-station and/or -building railway operating systems;  
(ii)  analyze operational practices for railway stations, buildings, and associated systems; 
and 
(iii)  study  the  best  international  design  practices  and  operational  experiences  for 
intelligent buildings (and particularly IRSBs) and adapt these to local conditions, 
then 
(a)  prepare recommendations for IRSB development for railway stations in the 
PRC, 
(b)  propose a method to assess energy efficiency and emissions for railway 
stations, and  
(c)  provide an action plan for developing IRSBs in the PRC that is realistic for 
the government and MOR to implement as well as a policy brief highlighting 
the TA’s main findings. 
 
2.  The consultants will perform their tasks in close consultation with MOR and other relevant 
agencies to ensure full acceptance of the TA’s outcome. The TA will require a total of 24 person-
months of consulting services (8 person-months international and 16 person-months national) to 
be implemented over a period of 6 months, including fieldwork. 
 
3.  The international intelligent building and energy efficiency specialist will be the team leader, 
with overall responsibility for coordinating the TA activities and generating the TA outputs with 
support  of  the  other  international  and  national  experts.  The  consultant  will  have  expertise  in 
managing  interdisciplinary  teams,  widely  ranging  experience  in  developing  intelligent  railway 
station buildings, and a full understanding of the other systems and their operation in railways. 
 
4.  The time estimated to complete the TA is from 23 April 2012 to 21 September 2012, and 
the consultants shall commence work within 30 calendar days of their contract’s effective date. 
 
B.  Consultants 
1.  Intelligent  Building  and  Energy  Efficiency  Specialists  (4  person-months 
international, 8 person-months national) 
 
5.  The consultants will undertake, but not necessarily be limited to, the following: 
(i)  review  the  existing  national  building  standard  for  the  energy  conservation  and 
current practices in the PRC for energy efficiency and emission reduction within the 
railway  sector  overall  and  the  railway  station  building  subsector  in  particular

(including station buildings and platforms), including policies, administrative systems, 
operations, and energy resources; 
(ii)  assess  the  design  principles  and  technical  criteria  of  railway  station  buildings 
adopted by MOR, and their associated systems covering architecture and building 
design;  safety,  fire  protection,  and  exit  systems;  heating,  ventilating,  and  air-
conditioning  systems;  hydraulic  and  drainage  systems;  and  in-building 
transportation systems; then analyze those systems’ operating characteristics with a 
view to improving energy efficiency, safety, and services quality through adopting 
intelligent building technologies; 
(iii)  conduct  a  study  on  international  best  practices  for  intelligent  buildings,  and  in 
particular  IRSBs,  including  (a)  architecture  and  building  design;  (b)  safety,  fire, 
protection, and exit systems; (c) heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning systems; 
(d) hydraulic and drainage systems, and (e) in-building transportation systems; 
(iv)  carry out a comprehensive analysis of international best practices for intelligent 
buildings, and IRSBs in particular, covering (a) technological features, (b) energy 
efficiency, (c) emission reduction, (d) costs versus benefits, (e) conditions for their 
use, and (f) their development trends; 
(v)  set up a database of good and/or best international practices for energy efficiency 
and emission reduction applicable to railway stations covering (a) technologies and 
systems, (b) design concepts and criteria, (c) operational management methods, 
and  (d)  strategic  management,  then  rank  those  practices  according  to  their 
efficiency, cost, and difficulty of implementation; 
(vi)  identify  the  direction  and  approach  to  developing  IRSBs  in  the  PRC,  covering 
policies, technologies, and design criteria; 
(vii)  while considering requirements (such as relating to climate) in specific zones, draft 
policy  recommendations  for  developing  IRSBs  in  the  PRC,  then  finalize  those 
recommendations in consultation with MOR, stakeholders, and relevant agencies; 
(viii)  select  typical  intelligent  buildings,  especially  IRSBs,  in  developed  countries  as 
overseas  training  and  study  models,  prepare  overseas  study  programs,  and 
coordinate the carrying out those programs; 
(ix)  review the current energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions status of the 
PRC railway stations based on field visits and consultations with MOR, railway 
administrative  bureaus,  and  other  stakeholders;  then  develop  a  method  for 
assessing energy efficiency and emissions that includes a detailed indicator system 
to monitor and assess the energy efficiency and emissions of PRC railway stations; 
and finally set up a baseline of those indicators for two selected railway stations; 
(x)  draft  a  practicable  action  plan  (including  a  recommended  IRSB  demonstration 
project that can be supported by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and replicated 
within the PRC and in other developing member countries) for implementing IRSB 
projects in the PRC; consult that action plan with MOR, stakeholders, and relevant 
agencies; then finalize the action plan so that MOR can implement it; and 
(xi)  while  incorporating  all  inputs  from  other  team  members,  prepare  a  policy  brief 
highlighting the best practices and findings of the policy and advisory technical 
assistance for dissemination to high-level policymakers and departments concerned 
in the government.

Appendix 3  11 
 
2.  Building  Automatic  Control  and  Data  Network  Specialists  (4 person-months 
international, 8 person-months national) 
 
6.  The consultants will undertake, but not necessarily be limited to, the following: 
(i)  undertake a detailed review and assessment of the current practices adopted by 
MOR for the design criteria and technical standards of railway station buildings; 
platforms; and their associated building automation systems, data and information 
systems, communication network systems, electrical installation systems, lighting 
systems, and in-station and/or -building railway operation systems; then analyze 
their operating characteristics, with a view to improving energy efficiency, safety, 
and services quality through adopting intelligent building technologies; 
(ii)  support selecting typical IRSBs and other intelligent buildings in developed countries 
as overseas training and study models, then coordinate in preparing and carrying 
out domestic and overseas training programs; 
(iii)  research international best practices for intelligent buildings and IRSBs, including 
building  automation  systems,  efficient  information  and  communication  network 
systems,  electrical  installation  systems,  lighting  systems,  and  in-station 
and/or -building railway operation systems, as well as integration of all systems 
associated with railway station buildings; 
(iv)  identify  gaps  in  the  systems  mentioned  in  (i)  and  (iii)  between  the  PRC  and 
developed countries and the direction in which the PRC railways can move forward; 
then  find  an  approach  to  developing  IRSBs  by  adopting  advanced  integrated 
systems with a view to improving energy efficiency, safety, and services quality 
through adopting intelligent building technologies; 
(v)  assist in carrying out a comprehensive analysis of international best practices for 
intelligent  buildings  and  IRSBs  covering  (a)  technological  features,  (b)  energy 
efficiency,  (c) emissions  reduction,  (d)  cost-benefit,  (e)  conditions  for  those 
practices’ use, and (f) their development trends; then build a database of good 
and/or best international practices for energy efficiency and emissions reduction 
applicable to railway stations;  
(vi)  assist in reviewing the current status of energy consumption and greenhouse gas 
emissions of the PRC railway stations, in developing a method for assessing energy 
efficiency and emissions that includes a detailed indicator system to monitor and 
assess the energy efficiency and emissions of PRC railway stations, and in setting 
up the baseline of those indicators for two selected railway stations; 
(vii)  draft policy recommendations on building automation systems, efficient information 
and  communication  network  systems,  electrical  installation  systems,  lighting 
systems,  and  in-station  and/or  -building  railway  operation  systems  in  railway 
stations for developing IRSBs in the PRC while considering requirements (such as 
relating to climate conditions and others) in specific zones and consulting with MOR, 
stakeholders, and relevant agencies; then finalize those recommendations; 
(viii)  draft a practicable action plan with regard to building automation systems, efficient 
information  and  communication  network  systems,  electrical  installation  systems, 
lighting systems, and railway operation systems in railway stations for implementing 
IRSB projects in the PRC; consult those action plans with MOR, stakeholders, and 
relevant agencies; then finalize the action plan so that MOR can implement it; and 
assist in proposing an IRSB demonstration project that can be supported by ADB; 
and

12  Appendix 3 
(ix)  assist in preparing a policy brief note highlighting the best practices and findings of 
the  policy  and  advisory  technical  assistance  for  dissemination  to  high-level 
policymakers and departments concerned in the government. 
 
7.  The international consultants should have at minimum 7 years of experience in energy 
efficiency, railway station building, electrified railway systems, railway electrical power systems, 
railway  operations,  and  IRSB  or  other  intelligent  building  project  development  plus  previous 
experience in projects funded by multilateral development banks, international financial institutions, 
and/or  international  development  agencies.  The  national  consultants  should  demonstrate 
experience in the design and construction of railway station buildings, electrified railway systems, 
electrical railway power systems, railway operations and other railway-related fields, and energy 
efficiency. They should be proficient in spoken and written English. 
 
8.  The consultants will review and build on previous studies and reports prepared by ADB, the 
World Bank, MOR, and/or other development partners. They will review lessons learned from past 
work and experience of other countries in developing similar projects. 
 
9.  The consultants will organize two workshops (one at the inception stage and the other at 
the interim stage) and present key findings during the workshops. One seminar at the final report 
stage  will  be  held for  the  consultants  to  disseminate  the  knowledge  from  the  study  and  the 
outcome of the work. 
 
C.  Reporting Requirements 
10.  The consultants will submit the following reports to MOR, the executing agency, and ADB: 
(i) an inception report 3 weeks after commencement of services, (ii) an interim report 10 weeks 
after commencement of services, (iii) a draft final report after 18 weeks, and (iv) a final report 
(including an executive summary including key findings and recommendations with five pages) 
2 weeks after receipt of review comments from the executing agency and ADB. 
 
11.  All reports will be written in English and translated into Chinese. Five hard copies and two 
soft copies of the inception, interim, and draft final reports (in English) will be submitted to ADB. 
Five hard copies and two soft copies of each report (in both Chinese and English) will be submitted 
to the executing agency. Fifty hard and two soft copies of the policy note in English will be 
submitted to ADB and 100 hard and two soft copies in both Chinese and English to the executing 
agency.
